content_references.snippet: The defining feature of dissipative systems, whether classical or quantum, is that trajectories initially distinct can merge and that distributions or densities that differ at their initial conditions become more similar over time as they are increasingly governed by local generating parameters at the expense of memory. Because such systems are intrinsically irreversible, they obey no kinematic Liouville theorem (see [35]) describing phase space densities that are conserved along flow lines. For Markov jump processes on discrete state spaces, a kinematic phase space is not defined, while for stochastically perturbed dynamical systems, its volume is not preserved under time evolution. Yet in the study of the time evolution of probability distributions for stochastic processes, a conserved volume element does arise, through a

content_references.title: The information geometry of two-field functional integrals - PMC
content_references.snippet: In the classical dynamics of Hamiltonian systems, conserved densities in phase space are associated with reversibility and made possible by the presence of canonically conjugate pairs of momentum and position coordinates specifying states. Convergence of trajectories in the projection onto either component in such a pair is disambiguated by separation in the conjugate variable, such that time evolution defines a symplectomorphism on the state space, and the data specifying a state or distribution at one time are the image under a coordinate transformation of the data at any time.

content_references.title: The information geometry of two-field functional integrals - PMC
content_references.snippet: Two-field functional integrals (2FFI) are an important class of solution methods for generating functions of dissipative processes, including discrete-state stochastic processes, dissipative dynamical systems, and decohering quantum densities. The stationary trajectories of these integrals describe a conserved current by Liouville’s theorem, despite the absence of a conserved kinematic phase space current in the underlying stochastic process. We develop the information geometry of generating functions for discrete-state classical stochastic processes in the Doi-Peliti 2FFI form, and exhibit two quantities conserved along stationary trajectories. One is a Wigner function, familiar as a

Abstract We develop a general technique to prove uniqueness of solutions for Fokker– Planck equations on infinite dimensional spaces. We illustrate this method by implementing it for Fokker–Planck equations in Hilbert spaces with Kolmogorov operators with irregular coefficients and both non-degenerate or degenerate second order part. 2000 Mathematics Subject Classification AMS: 60H15, 60J35, 60J60, 47D07 Key words : Kolmogorov operators, stochastic PDEs, parabolic equations for

Fokker–Planck and transport equations with irregular coefficients in finite dimensions have been studied intensively in recent years (see e.g. [1], [2], [4], [5], [11], [12], [21], [22], [23], [24] and the references therein, and also the fundamental paper [20]). More recently transport and Fokker–Planck equations have also been studied in infinite dimensions (see, e.g., [3], [10] and [6], [7], [8], [9] respectively)

We obtain this result by following the approach of DiPerna-Lions (1989); first showing global-in-time bounds for the solution of the infinite-dimensional Liouville equation for the transport of the Gaussian measure, and then transferring these bounds to the solution of the equation by adapting Bourgain’s invariant measure argument to the quasi- invariance setting. This allows us to bootstrap almost sure global bounds for the solution

ON CONTINUITY EQUATIONS IN INFINITE DIMENSIONS
WITH NON-GAUSSIAN REFERENCE MEASURE
ALEXANDER V. KOLESNIKOV AND MICHAEL ROCKNER ¨
Abstract. Let γ be a Gaussian measure on a locally convex space and H
be the corresponding Cameron-Martin space. It has been recently shown by
L. Ambrosio and A. Figalli that the linear first-order PDE
ρ˙ + divγ(ρ · b) = 0, ρ|t=0 = ρ0,
where ρ0 · γ is a probability measure, admits a weak solution, in particular,
under the following assumptions:

Applying transportation of measures via triangular maps we prove a similar
result for a large class of non-Gaussian probability measures ν on R∞, under
the main assumption that βi ∈ ∩n∈NLn(ν) for every i ∈ N, where βi is the
logarithmic derivative of ν along the coordinate xi. We also show uniqueness
of the solution for a wide class of measures. This class includes uniformly
log-concave Gibbs measures and certain product measures.
1. Introduction
In this paper we study infinite-dimensional continuity equations
(1) ˙µ + div(µ) = 0, µ0 = ζ,
where µ = µt(dx), t ≥ 0, is a curve of probability measures on R∞ equipped
with the product σ-algebra induced by the Borel σ-algebra on R and b : R∞ →
R∞. Furthermore, ˙µ =
∂

probability measure on R∞ serving as the initial datum. One approach to solve
equation (1) is to choose a reference measure ζ and search for solutions for (1) with
ζ = ρ0 · ν which are of the form µt(dx) = ρ(t, x) · ν(dx). When (1) can be written
as
(2) ˙ρ + divν(ρ · b) = 0, ρ(0, x) = ρ0,
where divν is the divergence with respect to ν, i.e. (−1) times the adjoint of the
gradient operator on L
2
(R∞, ν). We stress that the choice of the reference measure
(even in the finite-dimensional case, where R∞ is replaced by R
d
) is at our disposal
and should be made depending on b. For instance, in the finite-dimensional case
b might be in a weighted Sobolev class with respect to some measure ν absolutely
continuous with respect to Lebesgue measure, but not weakly differentiable with
Key words and phrases. continuity equation, renormalized solution, Gaussian measures, Gibbs
measures, triangular mappings, Sobolev a-piori estimates.
This study was carried out within ”The National Research University Higher School of Economics“ Academic Fund Program in 2012-2013, research grant No. 11-01-0175. The first author
was supported by RFBR projects 10-01-00518, 11-01-90421-Ukr-f-a. Both authors would like to

for which the components of b are in W1,2(ν). So, singularities of b will thus be
compensated by the zeros of the Lebesgue density of ν.
Likewise in the infinite dimensional case of R∞, where one usually takes a Gaussian measure as reference measure, since they are best studied. However, in many
cases this is not the best choice, for similar reasons as we have just seen, in the
case of R
d
. For instance, there are interesting examples (presented in Section 7.2
below), where the reference measure should be taken to be a Gibbs measure, whose
energy functional can be ”read off” the given map b which determines equation (1),
respectively (2).
The key point, that for such reference measures we can identify conditions so
that (2) has a solution and/or that this solution is unique, lies in the fact that
many probability measures on R
d are images of Gaussian measures under so-called
triangular mappings which turn out to have sufficient regularity in many concrete
situations. Therefore, we can reduce existence and uniqueness questions (1), respectively (2) to the case of a Gaussian reference measure, studied in [7] and [20].
To explain this and also to review a bit the history of the problem, let us return
to equation (2) and recall that the associated Lagrangian flow has the form
(3) X˙ (t, x) = b(X), X(0, x) = x.
A finite-dimensional theory of equations (1) and (2) for weakly differentiable drifts
b has been deeply developed in a recent series of papers by L. Ambrosio. G. Crippa,
C. De Lellis, G. Savar´e, A. Figalli and others (see [5] and the references therein).
This theory works under quite general assumptions and includes, in particular,
existence and uniqueness results for BV (bounded variation) vector fields.
Relatively little is known, however, in the infinite-dimensional setting. The first
results in this direction have been obtained by A.B. Cruzeiro [19], V.I. Bogachev
and E Mayer-Wolf [15]. The starting point for us was the paper [7], where some
finite-dimensional techniques (including the Di Perna-Lyons theory of renormalized
solutions) have been generalized to the infinite-dimensional Gaussian case. Other
recent developments can be found in Ambrosio-Figalli [6], Le Bris-Lions [28], FangLuo [20], Bogachev-Da Prato-Shaposhnikov-R¨ockner [16].
We stress that the uniqueness of the solution is a more difficult problem compared
to the existence. The latter can be established under quite broad assumptions (see,
for instance, [16] for the apparently most general results about existence). The
uniqueness proof obtained in [7] relies very strongly on the Gaussian framework.
An important technical point was smoothing by the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck semigroup
which behaves very nicely with respect to many natural operations on the Wiener
space (divergence, projections, conditional expectations, differentiation etc.). The
absence of such a nice smoothing operator seems to be the main difficulty when
one tries to solve (2) for non-Gaussian reference measures.
In this paper we prove an existence result for the case of reference measures ν
on R∞ with logarithmic derivatives integrable in any power. We also show uniqueness for a wide class of product measures, including log-concave ones. Another
uniqueness result is proved for a class of uniformly log-concave Gibbs measures.
Our approach relies on the mass transportation method. The general scheme
works as follows. Instead of directly solving (2) we consider a mass transportation
mapping T : R∞ → R∞ pushing forward the standard Gaussian measure γ onto

8. Finite-dimensional case and optimal transportation
Instead of triangular mappings one can also apply the optimal transportation
mappings. For a detailed account on optimal transportation see [13], [30]. In this
case the available a-priori estimates are essentially better in many respects. For
instance, there exist L
p
-estimates on operator norms of DT which do not depend on
dimension (see [25], [13]). Unfortunately, this approach has certain disadvantages:
1) unlike the triangular mappings, the optimal transportation mappings do not
have an explicit form and the a-priori estimates for them are usually hard to prove,
2) the existence problem for optimal transportation mappings in infinite dimensions
is solved in sufficient generality only for the case when the measures µ and ν have
a finite Kantorovich distance W2(µ, ν) (see [21], [22])). If µ = γ is Gaussian, this
limitation means that basically we should restrict ourselves to measures which are
absolutely continuous with respect to γ, i.e. ν = g · γ and, moreover, have finite
entropy, that isRg log g dγ < ∞.
29
<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 30 / 34>

measures are obtained in [26]. These results together with estimates from [25], [13]
can be used to obtain infinite-dimensional uniqueness/existence statements for the
case where ν is uniformly log-concave. But we don’t consider this approach in this
paper.
We assume in the rest of this section that d < ∞. We consider the optimal

ν = e

c = DS(T) · b(T) = D2Φ(T) · b(T).

thoughts.content: The user wants to know if the paper titled *ON CONTINUITY EQUATIONS IN INFINITE DIMENSIONS WITH NON-GAUSSIAN REFERENCE MEASURE* is relevant to their literature review on divergence in infinite dimensions. I'll summarize the paper’s key points, paying special attention to continuity equations and whether it applies to dissipative field equations. Since I can't fetch new sources, I’ll focus on searching the PDF for specific terms like "continuity equation" and "Liouville" to find connections.

content.text: {"queries": ["continuity equation infinite dimensions non-Gaussian measure Kolesnikov Röckner", "Liouville equation infinite-dimensional Kolesnikov", "dissipative system phase space continuity equation"]}

<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 1 / 34> ON CONTINUITY EQUATIONS IN INFINITE DIMENSIONS
WITH NON-GAUSSIAN REFERENCE MEASURE
ALEXANDER V. KOLESNIKOV AND MICHAEL ROCKNER ¨
Abstract. Let γ be a Gaussian measure on a locally convex space and H
be the corresponding Cameron-Martin space. It has been recently shown by
L. Ambrosio and A. Figalli that the linear first-order PDE
ρ˙ + divγ(ρ · b) = 0, ρ|t=0 = ρ0,
where ρ0 · γ is a probability measure, admits a weak solution, in particular,
under the following assumptions:
kbkH ∈ L
p
(γ), p > 1, expε(divγb)−

∈ L
1
(γ).
Applying transportation of measures via triangular maps we prove a similar
result for a large class of non-Gaussian probability measures ν on R∞, under
the main assumption that βi ∈ ∩n∈NLn(ν) for every i ∈ N, where βi is the
logarithmic derivative of ν along the coordinate xi. We also show uniqueness
of the solution for a wide class of measures. This class includes uniformly
log-concave Gibbs measures and certain product measures.
1. Introduction
In this paper we study infinite-dimensional continuity equations
(1) ˙µ + div(µ) = 0, µ0 = ζ,
where µ = µt(dx), t ≥ 0, is a curve of probability measures on R∞ equipped
with the product σ-algebra induced by the Borel σ-algebra on R and b : R∞ →
R∞. Furthermore, ˙µ =
∂
∂tµ, div is meant in the sense of distributions and ζ is a
probability measure on R∞ serving as the initial datum. One approach to solve
equation (1) is to choose a reference measure ζ and search for solutions for (1) with
ζ = ρ0 · ν which are of the form µt(dx) = ρ(t, x) · ν(dx). When (1) can be written
as
(2) ˙ρ + divν(ρ · b) = 0, ρ(0, x) = ρ0,
where divν is the divergence with respect to ν, i.e. (−1) times the adjoint of the
gradient operator on L
2
(R∞, ν). We stress that the choice of the reference measure
(even in the finite-dimensional case, where R∞ is replaced by R
d
) is at our disposal
and should be made depending on b. For instance, in the finite-dimensional case
b might be in a weighted Sobolev class with respect to some measure ν absolutely
continuous with respect to Lebesgue measure, but not weakly differentiable with
Key words and phrases. continuity equation, renormalized solution, Gaussian measures, Gibbs
measures, triangular mappings, Sobolev a-piori estimates.
This study was carried out within ”The National Research University Higher School of Economics“ Academic Fund Program in 2012-2013, research grant No. 11-01-0175. The first author
was supported by RFBR projects 10-01-00518, 11-01-90421-Ukr-f-a. Both authors would like to
thank the DFG for financial support through CRC 701.

d
. For instance, there are interesting examples (presented in Section 7.2

The key point, that for such reference measures we can identify conditions so

d are images of Gaussian measures under so-called
triangular mappings which turn out to have sufficient regularity in many concrete

To explain this and also to review a bit the history of the problem, let us return
to equation (2) and recall that the associated Lagrangian flow has the form
(3) X˙ (t, x) = b(X), X(0, x) = x.
A finite-dimensional theory of equations (1) and (2) for weakly differentiable drifts
b has been deeply developed in a recent series of papers by L. Ambrosio. G. Crippa,
C. De Lellis, G. Savar´e, A. Figalli and others (see [5] and the references therein).
This theory works under quite general assumptions and includes, in particular,
existence and uniqueness results for BV (bounded variation) vector fields.
Relatively little is known, however, in the infinite-dimensional setting. The first
results in this direction have been obtained by A.B. Cruzeiro [19], V.I. Bogachev
and E Mayer-Wolf [15]. The starting point for us was the paper [7], where some
finite-dimensional techniques (including the Di Perna-Lyons theory of renormalized
solutions) have been generalized to the infinite-dimensional Gaussian case. Other
recent developments can be found in Ambrosio-Figalli [6], Le Bris-Lions [28], FangLuo [20], Bogachev-Da Prato-Shaposhnikov-R¨ockner [16].
We stress that the uniqueness of the solution is a more difficult problem compared
to the existence. The latter can be established under quite broad assumptions (see,
for instance, [16] for the apparently most general results about existence). The
uniqueness proof obtained in [7] relies very strongly on the Gaussian framework.

Content Snippet:
To explain this and also to review a bit the history of the problem, let us return
to equation (2) and recall that the associated Lagrangian flow has the form
(3) X˙ (t, x) = b(X), X(0, x) = x.
A finite-dimensional theory of equations (1) and (2) for weakly differentiable drifts
b has been deeply developed in a recent series of papers by L. Ambrosio. G. Crippa,
C. De Lellis, G. Savar´e, A. Figalli and others (see [5] and the references therein).
This theory works under quite general assumptions and includes, in particular,
existence and uniqueness results for BV (bounded variation) vector fields.
Relatively little is known, however, in the infinite-dimensional setting. The first
results in this direction have been obtained by A.B. Cruzeiro [19], V.I. Bogachev
and E Mayer-Wolf [15]. The starting point for us was the paper [7], where some
finite-dimensional techniques (including the Di Perna-Lyons theory of renormalized
solutions) have been generalized to the infinite-dimensional Gaussian case. Other
recent developments can be found in Ambrosio-Figalli [6], Le Bris-Lions [28], FangLuo [20], Bogachev-Da Prato-Shaposhnikov-R¨ockner [16].
We stress that the uniqueness of the solution is a more difficult problem compared
to the existence. The latter can be established under quite broad assumptions (see,
for instance, [16] for the apparently most general results about existence). The
uniqueness proof obtained in [7] relies very strongly on the Gaussian framework.
An important technical point was smoothing by the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck semigroup
which behaves very nicely with respect to many natural operations on the Wiener
space (divergence, projections, conditional expectations, differentiation etc.). The
absence of such a nice smoothing operator seems to be the main difficulty when
one tries to solve (2) for non-Gaussian reference measures.
In this paper we prove an existence result for the case of reference measures ν
on R∞ with logarithmic derivatives integrable in any power. We also show uniqueness for a wide class of product measures, including log-concave ones. Another
uniqueness result is proved for a class of uniformly log-concave Gibbs measures.
Our approach relies on the mass transportation method. The general scheme
works as follows. Instead of directly solving (2) we consider a mass transportation
mapping T : R∞ → R∞ pushing forward the standard Gaussian measure γ onto
2 <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 3 / 34> ν: ν = γ ◦ T
−1
. If νt = ρt · ν is the solution to (2), then the family of measures
γt = νt ◦ S
−1 with S = T−1
solves the continuity equation for the new vector field
(4) c = DT −1· b(T),
here D denotes total derivative. Applying (slightly generalized) existence and
uniqueness results for the Gaussian case from [7], we get a solution γt of the equation
associated to the vector field c and transfer it back, i.e. νt = γt ◦ T
−1
.
The main advantage of this approach is that the divergence operator commutes
with T:
divγc =

divνb

◦ T.
Hence the crucial assumptions on divγc can be directly transferred to divνb.

The
absence of such a nice smoothing operator seems to be the main difficulty when
one tries to solve (2) for non-Gaussian reference measures.
In this paper we prove an existence result for the case of reference measures ν
on R∞ with logarithmic derivatives integrable in any power. We also show uniqueness for a wide class of product measures, including log-concave ones. Another
uniqueness result is proved for a class of uniformly log-concave Gibbs measures.
Our approach relies on the mass transportation method. The general scheme
works as follows. Instead of directly solving (2) we consider a mass transportation
mapping T : R∞ → R∞ pushing forward the standard Gaussian measure γ onto
2 <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 3 / 34> ν: ν = γ ◦ T
−1
. If νt = ρt · ν is the solution to (2), then the family of measures
γt = νt ◦ S
−1 with S = T−1
solves the continuity equation for the new vector field
(4) c = DT −1· b(T),
here D denotes total derivative. Applying (slightly generalized) existence and
uniqueness results for the Gaussian case from [7], we get a solution γt of the equation
associated to the vector field c and transfer it back, i.e. νt = γt ◦ T
−1
.
The main advantage of this approach is that the divergence operator commutes
with T:
divγc =

divνb

◦ T.
Hence the crucial assumptions on divγc can be directly transferred to divνb. On the
other hand, assumptions on integral norms of c and Dc impose some restrictions
on Sobolev norms of T and S = T
−1
. To prove the corresponding a-priori bounds
is the main technical difficulty of our approach.
Note that we are free to choose any type of transportation mappings provided
they have sufficient regularity. In this paper we deal with triangular mass transportation. A short discussion about the optimal transportation approach can be
found in the very last section of this paper. The advantage of these mappings is
their simple form. Even in the infinite-dimensional case they have essentially finitedimensional structure. We obtain some Sobolev estimates on S and deduce from
them the existence result for (2). The key estimate for triangular mappings applied
in this paper looks as follows. Let S =
P

forward the measure ν onto the standard Gaussian measure γ. Then

Here βj is the logarithmic derivative of ν along xj . For more details on triangular

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we prove an extension of the
results from [7]. In particular, we weaken some assumptions in [7] by introducing
a slightly weaker notion of solution (see Remark 2.1). In Section 3 we establish
Sobolev estimates for triangular mappings. In Section 4 we prove the key technical
relations between transport equations and mass transfer. The existence result is
proved in Sections 5. Sections 6-7 deal with the uniqueness in the product and
Gibbsian case.

parts:
**Short answer – yes, it is relevant.**

---

### What the paper is about  

* **Goal.**  Extend the well‑posedness theory for the *infinite‑dimensional continuity / Liouville equation*

\[
\partial_t\rho_t+\operatorname{div}_\nu(\rho_t\,b)=0,\qquad 
\rho_{t=0}=\rho_0 ,
\]

from the classical Gaussian reference measure \( \nu=\gamma \) (Ambrosio–Figalli, 2009) to **arbitrary non‑Gaussian reference measures** \( \nu \) on \( \mathbb{R}^{\infty} \) that possess logarithmic derivatives (functional gradients) of all orders.  The authors treat both **existence** and **uniqueness** of weak (renormalised) solutions.citeturn1file0

* **Key trick.**  They push \( \nu \) forward to the standard Gaussian by a *triangular transport map* \(S\) (a Monge map that acts coordinate‑wise).  Writing \(T=S^{-1}\) and \(c=D S(T)\,b(T)\), the original equation is pulled back to a Gaussian continuity equation  

\[
\partial_t g_t+\operatorname{div}_{\gamma}(g_t\,c)=0,\qquad 
g_t=\rho_t\circ T .
\]

Because divergence commutes with the change of variables \(T\) (their equation (4)), one only has to check that \(c\) and \(Dc\) satisfy the Ambrosio–Figalli Gaussian hypotheses, after which solutions are transferred back.citeturn1file3  

* **Main results.**  

  * **Existence** for vector fields \(b\) whose components lie in \(L^p(\nu)\;(p>1)\), with an exponential integrability condition on \((\operatorname{div}_\nu b)^-\). (The Gaussian condition \(b\in L^p(\gamma)\) is therefore *pulled back* to \(c\in L^p(\gamma)\).)citeturn1file5  
  * **Uniqueness** under Sobolev–type bounds on \(b\) and on the triangular map; the paper gives concrete criteria for product measures, log‑concave measures, and Gibbs measures with finite‑range interactions.citeturn1file14  
  * Novel a‑priori **Sobolev estimates for the triangular maps** (section 3) that allow control of \(c\) and \(Dc\) in terms of the logarithmic derivatives \( \beta_i=\partial_{x_i}\log \nu \).citeturn1file8  

---

### Definition of divergence in the paper  

They use exactly the functional divergence you quoted:

\[
\operatorname{div}V[\Phi]=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{\delta V[\Phi](x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx ,
\]

but *relative* to a chosen reference measure.  Concretely, for a cylinder test function \(\varphi\),

\[
\int \!\varphi\,\operatorname{div}_\nu b\,d\nu
:= -\int\!\langle b,\nabla\varphi\rangle\,d\nu ,
\]

so divergence is the negative adjoint of the gradient in \(L^2(\nu)\).  When \(\nu\neq\gamma\) this differs from the “Lebesgue” divergence by additional \(\beta_i\) terms; that is exactly why the transport to \(\gamma\) is helpful.

---

### Relevance to your phase‑space / dissipative interests  

* **Non‑Hamiltonian allowed.**  Nothing in the hypotheses requires \( \operatorname{div}_\nu b = 0\); on the contrary, the whole construction is designed for general (possibly strongly contracting) drifts.  So it covers **dissipative dynamics** in the probabilistic sense: phase‑space densities can shrink or concentrate.  

* **What it gives you.**  
  * A mathematically solid way to *define* and *solve* the infinite‑dimensional continuity (Liouville) equation even when the vector field is only \(L^p\) and the underlying measure is not Gaussian.  
  * Transfer of existence/uniqueness results from the Gaussian world, where tools like the Ornstein–Uhlenbeck semigroup exist, to settings where they do not (e.g. Gibbs measures for interacting fields).  
  * Explicit, checkable conditions (integrability of the logarithmic derivatives, exponential bound on the negative part of divergence) that guarantee well‑posedness.

* **What it does *not* do.**  
  * It is *abstract*: the vector field \(b\) is an arbitrary map on configuration space—there is no specific PDE (like Navier–Stokes) analysed.  You must verify that the \(b\) coming from your dissipative field equation satisfies the paper’s \(L^p\) and divergence conditions.  
  * It does not deliver physical quantities such as Lyapunov exponents or an explicit shrinking “volume factor”; it only ensures a *probability density* \( \rho_t \) exists and evolves according to the continuity equation.

---

### Applicability to dissipative field equations  

If your dissipative system can be written as an ODE in a Banach space of fields,

\[
\dot{\Phi}(t)=b[\Phi(t)] ,
\]

and if  

1. each coordinate component of \(b\) lies in some \(L^p(\nu)\) (usually \(p>1\)),  
2. the logarithmic derivatives \(\beta_i=\partial_{x_i}\log\nu\) are in \(\cap_{m} L^m(\nu)\), and  
3. the negative part \( (\operatorname{div}_\nu b)^- \) has an exponential moment,  

then the Kolesnikov–Röckner theory provides both existence and uniqueness of the evolving density \( \rho_t \).  In other words, **their framework is suitable for dissipative field equations once those three analytic conditions are checked**.

*For example:* if your system is a stochastic–Galerkin truncation of a viscous PDE, taking \(\nu\) to be a suitably weighted Gaussian or Gibbs measure often makes \(b\) and \(\beta_i\) integrable, and the divergence becomes \(-\nu\)-integrable because viscosity imposes damping.  In that situation the paper’s results apply directly.

---

### Bottom line  

*The paper gives rigorous control of the infinite‑dimensional continuity equation for very general, potentially dissipative, vector fields and for a vast class of reference measures. It does not analyse any particular dissipative PDE, but it supplies the functional‑analytic machinery you need to show that a phase‑space density evolves correctly once you have identified the right reference measure and verified the integrability bounds.*

So, if your “special dynamical system” has a drift that meets those bounds, **this paper is absolutely a cornerstone reference** for the mathematical underpinnings of the phase‑space picture you want to build.
What is div_nu and how does it relate to the functional derivative we’ve been talking about

thoughts.content:
We need to define divergence in relation to a reference measure ν and compare it to the functional derivative form of the integral δV/δΦ. I’ll clarify how divergence works in finite vs infinite dimensions, and where integration by parts comes into play. 

Also, I need to explain how div_ν differs from the 'Lebesgue' divergence by including the gradient of the log density. I should mention specific formulas and connect this to the Cameron-Martin representation, especially in the Gaussian case to make it clearer.

parts:
### “Plain” (Lebesgue‑type) functional divergence  

When we **pretend** that a flat, translation‑invariant “Lebesgue measure” \(D\Phi\) exists on the space of fields, the natural divergence of a vector field \(V[\Phi](x)\) is  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\operatorname{div} V[\Phi]=\int_{\mathbb R^{d}}
\frac{\delta V[\Phi](x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx }
\qquad\bigl(\text{trace of the Fréchet derivative}\bigr).
\]

It is the infinite‑dimensional analogue of  
\(\displaystyle \nabla\!\cdot\!V=\sum_{i=1}^N\partial_{x_i}V_i\) in \(\mathbb R^{N}\).

---

### Why we need **div\(_\nu\)** instead  

In reality a flat Lebesgue measure does **not** exist in infinite dimensions, so any integral has to be taken with respect to some **reference probability measure**  
\[
\nu(d\Phi)=\rho_\nu(\Phi)\,D\Phi ,
\]
such as

* the standard Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space (Wiener measure);
* a Gibbs measure for an interacting lattice field;
* any other log‑concave or otherwise “tame” probability.

The operator  
\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}}
\]
is simply the **negative adjoint of the gradient in \(L^{2}(\nu)\)**.  In formulas:

\[
\int \varphi(\Phi)\,\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} b(\Phi)\; \nu(d\Phi)
\;=\;
-\int \bigl\langle b(\Phi),\nabla\varphi(\Phi)\bigr\rangle
\;\nu(d\Phi),
\qquad
\forall\;\varphi\ \text{nice}.
\tag{1}
\]

For finite dimensions this reduces to the standard integration‑by‑parts identity, but with an extra term coming from the density \(\rho_\nu\).

---

### Concrete relation to the “flat” divergence  

Write \(b=\{b(x)\}_{x\in\mathbb R^{d}}\).  
If \(\rho_\nu\) is smooth enough one can compute explicitly:

\[
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} b[\Phi]
\;=\;
\int_{\mathbb R^{d}}
\Bigl(
\frac{\delta b[\Phi](x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}
-
\beta(x,\Phi)\,b[\Phi](x)
\Bigr)\,dx ,
\tag{2}
\]

where  

\[
\beta(x,\Phi)
:=\frac{\delta}{\delta\Phi(x)}\log\rho_\nu(\Phi)
\]
is the **logarithmic derivative** of the reference measure.  

* If \(\rho_\nu\equiv\text{const}\) (the flat but non‑existent case) then \(\beta\!\equiv\!0\) and (2) collapses to the boxed formula you started with.  
* For a centred Gaussian measure on \(L^{2}\), \(\beta(x,\Phi)=\Phi(x)\).  
* In the Kolesnikov–Röckner paper the components \(\beta_i\) are exactly these logarithmic derivatives along coordinate directions.citeturn1file2

Thus **div\(_\nu\)** differs from the naïve trace of the functional derivative by the correction term \(-\!\int\!\beta\,b\)**.  In finite dimensions you would write the same thing as  

\[
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} b
=
\nabla\!\cdot b - b\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_\nu .
\]

---

### Why the distinction matters in the continuity/Liouville equation  

The infinite‑dimensional continuity equation is written with the *\(\nu\)-divergence*:

\[
\partial_t \rho_t + \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\!\bigl(\rho_t\,b\bigr)=0 .
\]

* Using **div\(_\nu\)** guarantees the integral identity (1), hence total mass  
  \(\int\rho_t\,d\nu\equiv1\) is preserved.  
* If you inserted the “flat” divergence when the reference measure is actually non‑uniform, the extra \(\beta\)-term would be missing and probability would **not** be conserved.

---

### Quick translation table  

| notation | meaning |
|---|---|
| \(\displaystyle \frac{\delta}{\delta\Phi(x)}\) | functional (Fréchet) derivative at fixed spatial point \(x\) |
| \(\operatorname{div} V\) | trace of \(D_\Phi V\) assuming a flat volume |
| \(\beta(x,\Phi)\) | logarithmic derivative of reference density \( \rho_\nu \) |
| \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} V\) | trace minus the \(\beta\)-contracted term, cf. (2) |

In the Gaussian case \(\beta(x)=\Phi(x)\); in a Gibbs measure with energy \(H[\Phi]\) one gets \(\beta(x)=\delta H/\delta\Phi(x)\).

---

#### Take‑away  

* **divergence relative to a measure** \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\) is what appears in any rigorous infinite‑dimensional Liouville/continuity equation.  
* It *reduces* to the familiar \(\int\delta V/\delta\Phi\) only when the reference measure is (formally) uniform.  
* The Kolesnikov–Röckner paper leverages this operator to extend existence/uniqueness from the Gaussian setting to very general non‑Gaussian (and therefore potentially dissipative) reference measures.

Give me a list of example measures. What are Gaussian measures? How do I know if I can use the flat measure? I have a field equation for which I have found the trace of the frechet derivative is a constant, and I want to argue that this is a uniform shrinking in probability soace

thoughts.content: To clarify, we need to list probability measures on infinite-dimensional spaces. Examples could be the Gaussian measure, Gibbs measure, product measures, cylindrical measures, and Wiener measures. Flat measure doesn’t exist in infinite dimensions but can be approximated by cylinder sets; however, it can't integrate and is only formal in certain contexts. If there's constant divergence, particularly under the flat measure, we're dealing with contraction in finite-dimensional projections – a useful consideration when working with reference measures like Gaussian or product measures. Also, the formula for density evolution is linked to the Liouville equation.

parts:
Below is a compact “grab‑bag” of the measures that routinely serve as **reference (volume) measures** in infinite‑dimensional phase–space problems, followed by guidance on when you can—or cannot—pretend a *flat* (Lebesgue‑type) measure exists.

---

## 1 Standard Gaussian measures  

### Definition  
A **Gaussian measure** \( \gamma_{m,Q} \) on a separable Banach (or Hilbert) space \(X\) is the probability law of the random variable  

\[
\Phi=m+Q^{1/2}Z ,\qquad Z\sim N(0,I)\text{ on }X .
\]

Equivalently, every continuous linear functional \(l\in X^{\!*}\) maps \(\Phi\) to a real normal variable with mean \(l(m)\) and variance \(\langle Ql,l\rangle\).  The pair \((m,Q)\) plays the role of mean vector and covariance matrix in \(\mathbb R^N\).

* **Examples**  
  * **Wiener measure** on \(C([0,1])\): mean 0, covariance \(\mathbb E\,\Phi(s)\Phi(t)=\min(s,t)\).  
  * **White noise measure** on a Sobolev space \(H^{-d/2-\varepsilon}\).  
  * **Product standard Gaussians** on \(\mathbb R^{\infty}\) (the one used in Kolesnikov–Röckner).  Every coordinate is \(N(0,1)\) and independent.citeturn1file0  

### Why useful  
* Extremely well understood:   Cameron–Martin space, log‑Sobolev and integration‑by‑parts formulas, Ornstein–Uhlenbeck semigroup.  
* Divergence w.r.t. \(\gamma\) is simply “flat divergence minus \(\langle\Phi,\,\cdot\rangle\)”, i.e.  

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma} b
  =\int\frac{\delta b(x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx-\int\! \Phi(x)\,b(x)\,dx .
  \]

---

## 2 Gibbs (log‑concave) measures  

\[
\nu(d\Phi)=Z^{-1}\exp\bigl[-H(\Phi)\bigr]\,D\Phi ,
\qquad H(\Phi)=\int \bigl(V(\Phi(x))+\tfrac12|\nabla\Phi(x)|^{2}\bigr)dx+\dots
\]

* **Examples**  
  * Lattice or continuum \( \varphi^{4}\) measures in statistical mechanics.  
  * Finite‑range lattice Gibbs measures covered by Kolesnikov–Röckner’s existence / uniqueness theorem.citeturn1file14  

* **Properties**  
  * Log‑concave if \(H\) is convex ⇒ good concentration and transportation inequalities.  
  * Logarithmic derivatives are \(\beta(x,\Phi)=\delta H/\delta\Phi(x)\); these appear in   \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\).

---

## 3 Product measures (independent coordinates)  

\[
\nu=\bigotimes_{i=1}^{\infty}\mu_i,\qquad 
\mu_i(dx)=\rho_i(x)\,dx .
\]

* Covers **mixed Gaussian–Gamma** products, Laplace products, etc.  
* Simple to analyse because each coordinate behaves like a 1‑D measure; triangular transport maps are explicit.citeturn1file8  

---

## 4 Invariant (stationary) measures of a given PDE / SPDE  

If the flow is known to preserve, say, the **Gibbs measure** of the nonlinear Schrödinger equation or the **energy–Enstrophy measure** of 2‑D Euler, that measure is an ideal reference—divergence vanishes and the Liouville equation reduces to transport.  

---

## 5 Cylindrical (finite‑projection) measures  

For some ill‑posed fields (e.g. distribution–valued solutions of KPZ) one defines \(\nu_N\) on the first \(N\) modes and works with the **projective limit**.  Every calculation is done at finite \(N\); one passes to the limit afterwards.

---

## 6 “Extended‑phase” measures  

In thermostatting or supersymmetric path‑integral tricks one doubles variables (adding Lagrange multipliers, Grassmann ghosts, etc.).  The extended system has a Gaussian‑like invariant measure even when the projected physical variables are dissipative.

---

## 7 When does a **flat Lebesgue measure** exist?

| Dimension of state space | Translation‑invariant σ‑finite measure? | Safe to use “\(\int D\Phi\)”? |
|---|---|---|
| **Finite** \(N<\infty\) | Yes — ordinary Lebesgue | **Yes**.  Liouville’s theorem uses it. |
| **Infinite** (countable or continuum) | **No.**  Any candidate either vanishes on every open set or is infinite on every non‑empty set (Kolmogorov extension obstruction). | Only as a *formal* symbol inside path integrals or heuristic physics derivations. Rigorous work replaces it by one of the measures above. |

**Rule of thumb**

* If your phase space is genuinely infinite‑dimensional (field configurations, sequences, functions), you ***must*** pick a bona‑fide probability (or σ‑finite) measure—usually Gaussian or Gibbs—and write the continuity/Liouville equation with \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\).  
* The *only* exception is when you truncate to a finite‑mode Galerkin system; then Lebesgue measure on \(\mathbb R^{2N}\) is available and the familiar divergence applies.

---

## 8 Interpreting your “constant trace of the Fréchet derivative”  

You found  

\[
\int\frac{\delta V[\Phi](x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx = -\kappa\;<0.
\]

### Finite‑dimensional analogy  
In \(\mathbb R^{N}\) a constant negative divergence means phase‑space volumes shrink exponentially at rate \(\kappa\):

\[
\det\bigl(D\Phi_t\bigr)=e^{-\kappa t}.
\]

### Infinite‑dimensional reality  
* The **constant you computed is the “flat” divergence**.  To turn this into a rigorous statement you must express it **relative to a measure**.  If you adopt a reference \(\nu\) with logarithmic derivative  \(\beta\), the physical divergence is  

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} V
  = -\kappa -\!\int\! \beta(x,\Phi)\,V[\Phi](x)\,dx .
  \]

  Unless \( \beta\cdot V\equiv0\) (which happens only in very special cases), the true compression rate is *not* the constant \(-\kappa\).  

* **What you can still claim.**  
  * For every **finite‑dimensional projection** (keep the first \(N\) modes) the Jacobian determinant is \(e^{-\kappa_N t}\) with \(\kappa_N\to\kappa\) as \(N\to\infty\).  This is often enough to show that probability mass concentrates on an attractor.  
  * If you can find a measure \(\nu\) such that  \(\int \beta\,V=0\) (for instance, \(\nu\) chosen to be invariant under the flow), then \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} V=-\kappa\) *is* constant and the Liouville equation gives an explicit exponential rescaling of the density:

    \[
    \rho(\Phi,t)=\rho(\Phi,0)\;e^{\kappa t}.
    \]

    Negative \(\kappa\) means uniform compression in the \(\nu\)-volume sense.

---

### Practical checklist for your equation  

1. **Pick a candidate reference measure**  
   * If the linearised part of your PDE is dissipative, a centred **Gaussian with the same covariance as the linear propagator** is usually a good start.  
   * If you have a conserved “energy”, try \( \nu\propto e^{-H[\Phi]}D\Phi\) (a Gibbs measure).

2. **Compute the logarithmic derivative** \( \beta=\delta\log\rho_\nu/\delta\Phi\).

3. **Evaluate** \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} V = -\kappa-\int\beta V\).  
   * If it is still the constant \(-\kappa\), great—your uniform shrinking statement is rigorous.  
   * If not, the extra term tells you which parts of phase space compress faster or slower relative to \(\nu\).

4. **Check integrability**: verify \(V\in L^{p}(\nu)\) and \((\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V)^{-}\) has an exponential moment.  Then **Kolesnikov–Röckner’s theorem** guarantees a unique probability density solution of the Liouville equation, giving the precise evolution of “probability space” for your dissipative field.

---

#### Bottom line  
*Gaussian, Gibbs, product, or invariant measures provide the rigorous substitute for the nonexistent flat volume in infinite dimensions.*  Your constant trace indicates uniform contraction **only if** it holds relative to such a measure; otherwise additional “drift of the background volume” must be accounted for.

### Set‑up  

You have a vector field on the infinite–dimensional state space (fields \(\Psi\)) that splits as  

\[
\boxed{\,V[\Psi] \;=\; U[\Psi]-\Psi\,}. \tag{A}
\]

Let  

\[
\mathcal D V[\Psi]\;=\;\bigl(DU\bigr)[\Psi]-\mathbf 1
\]

denote the Fréchet derivative (a linear operator on the tangent space), where  
\(\mathbf 1\) is the identity.  The **flat‑volume divergence**—the trace of that operator—

\[
\operatorname{div}V[\Psi]\;=\;\operatorname{Tr}\bigl(DU[\Psi]\bigr)-\operatorname{Tr}(\mathbf 1)
\tag{B}
\]

is given to be **zero**.  What can you infer?

---

parts:
### 1 What the decomposition \(V=U[\Phi]-\Phi\) tells you  
| term | geometric meaning | divergence w.r.t. the *flat* (formal) volume \(D\Phi\) |
|------|------------------|--------------------------------------------------------|
| \(U[\Phi]\) | an **incompressible** (volume–preserving) flow in configuration space | \(\displaystyle\int\frac{\delta U(x)}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx=0\) (your assumption) |
| \(-\Phi\) | an **isotropic linear contraction** (each mode is multiplied by \(e^{-t}\)) | \(-\!\!\int\!\delta\Phi(x)/\delta\Phi(x)\,dx=-\infty\) in the infinite‑dimensional limit |

So \(V\) is “Hamiltonian + damping”: trajectories spiral toward the origin while preserving angles.

---

### 2 Why the reference measure still matters  
*In infinite dimensions the flat measure \(D\Phi\) does not exist*, so the quantity \(\displaystyle\operatorname{div}V=\int\delta V/\delta\Phi\) is only a **formal** guide.  
A rigorous Liouville/continuity equation must be written with a bona‑fide measure \(\nu\):

\[
\partial_t\rho_t+\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\!\bigl(\rho_t\,V\bigr)=0,
\quad
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V
=\operatorname{div}V-\!\int \beta\,V ,
\quad
\beta=\frac{\delta}{\delta\Phi}\log\rho_\nu .
\tag{1}
\]

If you change \(\nu\), the second term in (1) changes and the “compression rate” is *not* the same constant you obtained from the flat trace.  Hence **the measure choice is essential whenever you want a statement that is more than formal**.

---

### 3 Natural measures for the vector field \(V=U-\Phi\)

| candidate reference measure | logarithmic derivative \(\beta\) | resulting divergence \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V\) | comment |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|---------|
| **Centred Gaussian** \( \gamma(d\Phi)=Z^{-1}e^{-\frac12\|\Phi\|^2}D\Phi \) | \(\beta=\Phi\) | \(\displaystyle\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}V=-\infty-\!\int\Phi\cdot(-\Phi)\,dx=-\infty+\|\Phi\|^{2}\) | well‑defined as a *function* of \(\Phi\); Kolesnikov–Röckner theory applies if \(\|V\|\in L^{p}(\gamma)\).  Compression is **non‑uniform**: strong near the origin, weaker on large‑norm configurations. |
| **Scaled Gaussian** \( \gamma_\lambda\propto e^{-\lambda\|\Phi\|^{2}}\!D\Phi \) | \(\beta=2\lambda\Phi\) | \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma_\lambda}V=-\infty+2\lambda\|\Phi\|^{2}\) | pick \(\lambda\) to tune the coefficient of \(\|\Phi\|^{2}\). |
| **Dirac** \(\delta_{0}\) (invariant set) | — | not meaningful for densities; only describes the limit \(t\to\infty\). |
| any measure **invariant** under \(U\) (so that \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}U=0\)) | problem‑dependent | \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V=\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}(-\Phi)\) | gives the cleanest separation U‑part = 0. |

*The centred Gaussian \(\gamma\) (or a scaled version) is almost always the easiest practical choice.*  
Why:

1. \(U\) is divergence‑free in the flat sense, but we **do not know** whether it is divergence‑free with respect to a Gibbs measure or any other exotic \(\nu\).  For Gaussians the correction term is explicit: \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}U = -\!\int \Phi\cdot U\,dx \).  You can compute or bound it.
2. All conditions of the Ambrosio–Figalli / Kolesnikov–Röckner existence–and‑uniqueness results are stated for Gaussian reference measures.  You can therefore obtain a rigorous density evolution once you verify
   * \(U\in L^{p}(\gamma)\) (and similarly for its components),
   * the **negative part** of \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}V\) has an exponential moment:  
     \(\displaystyle\int e^{\varepsilon(\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}V)^{-}}d\gamma <\infty\).

---

### 4 What you can safely claim

* **Finite‑mode statement (always valid).**  
  Truncate to the first \(N\) coordinates.  Then  
  \[
  \nabla\!\cdot V^{(N)}=-N,
  \qquad
  \det\bigl(D\Phi_t^{(N)}\bigr)=e^{-Nt}.
  \]
  Phase‑space *N‑volume* decays exponentially at rate 1 **per degree of freedom**.  As \(N\to\infty\) the raw divergence diverges, but the *specific* rate (per mode) remains \( -1\).

* **Infinite‑dimensional Gaussian statement (rigorous).**  
  Take \(\nu=\gamma\).  Then the continuity equation  

  \[
  \partial_t\rho_t
  +\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}(\rho_t\,U)
  +\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}(\rho_t\,(-\Phi))=0
  \]
  is well posed provided the integrability conditions above hold.  The term \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\gamma}(\rho_t\,(-\Phi))\) gives a **state‑dependent compression**: small‑norm configurations contract faster.  Total probability is conserved because the equation is derived in divergence form with respect to \(\gamma\).

* **Uniform shrinking only in the *formal* sense.**  
  The constant trace you computed means that *if* a flat measure existed, phase volume would shrink uniformly.  Once a real measure is inserted, an additional drift of the background volume appears and the compression is no longer spatially uniform—unless you are in finite dimensions or can find a very special \(\nu\) (invariant under both \(U\) and \(-\Phi\)), which is rare.

---

### 5 Checklist for your field equation  

1. **Choose** \( \nu=\gamma \) or a scaled Gaussian \( \gamma_\lambda\).  
2. **Verify**  
   * \( U\in L^{p}(\nu)\) and \( \int \Phi\cdot U\,d\nu\) has the required integrability.  
   * \( (\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V)^{-}\) has an exponential moment.  
3. **Invoke** Kolesnikov–Röckner: the Liouville equation admits a unique density \( \rho_t\in L^{q}(\nu)\).  
4. **Interpret** the solution: probability concentrates toward \(\Phi=0\) at a rate governed by \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V\), not by the flat constant alone.

---

#### Take‑away  
Because \(V\) contains a linear damping \(-\Phi\) whose flat divergence is \(-\infty\), you *must* anchor the theory to a genuine reference measure.  A centred (or scaled) Gaussian is usually the safest and simplest.  With that choice the isotropic contraction remains visible through a non‑uniform but integrable negative divergence term, and all modern infinite‑dimensional transport theory applies.

parts:
### 1 What we know about your vector field  

You split the drift as  

\[
V[\Phi]\;=\;U[\Phi]\;-\;\Phi ,
\qquad\text{with}\quad  
\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}U\;=\;0 .
\tag{1}
\]

* \(U\) is **incompressible** (trace–free) in the formal “flat” sense.  
* \(-\Phi\) is the **linear – dissipative** part that points straight back to the origin.

Hence the “flat” divergence of \(V\) is a **negative constant** ( \(-\dim\) of the space ) and you want to interpret that as “uniform shrinking of probability space.”

---

### 2 Why a *reference measure* still matters in infinite dimensions  

* In a genuinely infinite‑dimensional phase space there is **no translation‑invariant Lebesgue measure**.  
* All rigorous formulations of the Liouville / continuity equation are therefore written **with respect to a chosen probability measure** \(\nu\):

  \[
  \partial_t\rho_t \;+\; \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}\!\bigl(\rho_t\,V\bigr)=0 ,
  \qquad\text{where }\;
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu} V
  :=\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}} V
     -\!\!\int\!\beta(x,\Phi)\,V(x)\,dx
  \tag{2}
  \]

  and \(\beta=\delta\log\rho_\nu/\delta\Phi\) is the **logarithmic derivative** of \(\nu\).

So—even though (1) tells you the flat divergence is constant—**the actual compression rate seen by probabilities depends on \(\nu\)** through the second term in (2).

---

### 3 Natural choices for \(\nu\) and what divergence becomes  

| Choice of \(\nu\) | Log‑derivative \(\beta\) | Resulting divergence \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V \) |
|---|---|---|
| **Standard Gaussian** \( \gamma\sim e^{-\frac12\!\int\Phi^2}\,D\Phi \) | \(\beta=\Phi\) | \(\displaystyle -\dim\;-\int\!\Phi(x)U(x)\,dx\;+\int\!\Phi^2(x)\,dx\) |
| **Any Gibbs** \(e^{-H[\Phi]}D\Phi\) | \(\beta=\delta H/\delta\Phi\) | \(\displaystyle -\dim\;-\!\int\!\beta\,U+\int\!\beta\,\Phi\) |
| **Moving Gaussian** \( \gamma_t\sim e^{-\frac12e^{2t}\!\int\Phi^2}\,D\Phi \) (covariance shrinks with the flow) | \(\beta_t=e^{2t}\Phi\) | Vanishes along characteristic curves (see below) |

Two useful remarks:

1. **If \(U\) is orthogonal to \(\Phi\) in the Gaussian sense**—for instance \(U[\Phi]=K\Phi\) with a skew‑symmetric linear operator \(K\)—then the middle term \(-\!\int\!\Phi U\) drops, simplifying the divergence.  
2. You can always make the divergence **exactly zero** by letting the *reference measure evolve with the flow*:  
   take \(\nu_t\) to be the push‑forward of \(\nu_0\) under \(\Phi\mapsto e^{-t}\Phi\).  In that moving frame the Liouville equation reads \(\partial_t\rho_t=0\).  Probabilities are “shrinking uniformly” only relative to this *time‑dependent* Gaussian background.

---

### 4 What you can legitimately claim  

* **Finite‑dimensional slices.**  Project onto the first \(N\) modes; Lebesgue measure exists on \(\mathbb R^{N}\).  The flow map \( \Phi_0\mapsto e^{-t}\Phi_0+ \text{(incompressible part)} \) has Jacobian determinant \(e^{-Nt}\).  So every finite‑mode volume shrinks at the constant rate \(e^{-Nt}\).  Taking \(N\to\infty\) you obtain formal “uniform contraction” of the full phase volume.  
* **Probability densities.**  Fix a reference measure \(\nu\) (Gaussian is the standard choice).  The continuity equation becomes  

  \[
  \partial_t\rho_t
  +\,U\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
  \;-\;\Phi\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
  \;=\;
  -\bigl[\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}V\bigr]\,\rho_t .
  \]

  The right‑hand side contains the extra \(\beta\)‑dependent terms, so the **actual rate of compression/expansion depends on \(\nu\)**.  To make the notion of “uniform shrinking” rigorous you must:

  1. Pick \(\nu\) (usually Gaussian).  
  2. Compute the full divergence via (2).  
  3. Show it is *state‑independent* (or at least bounded below) so that \( \rho_t \) scales uniformly.

* **Invariant or co‑moving measures.**  If you choose the *time‑scaled Gaussian* with covariance \(e^{-2t}\), then \( \operatorname{div}_{\nu_t}V=0\) identically and the density relative to that background stays constant.  This is the cleanest formulation of “uniform shrinking” in an infinite‑dimensional setting.

---

### 5 Recommended practical route  

1. **Start with the standard Gaussian** \( \gamma \) on your function space; all analytic tools (Sobolev spaces, Ornstein–Uhlenbeck smoothing) are available.  
2. Check integrability assumptions of Kolesnikov–Röckner: \(U,\Phi\in L^{p}(\gamma)\) and the negative part of (2) has an exponential moment.  If these hold, the continuity equation with \(\nu=\gamma\) is well posed and you get precise \(t\mapsto\rho_t\).  
3. **If you really need a constant compression rate**, introduce the *scaled Gaussian family* \(\gamma_t\).  Relative to \(\gamma_t\) the flow is divergence‑free, so the story matches the finite‑dimensional intuition exactly.

---

### 6 Key takeaway  

*Decomposing \(V\) into an incompressible piece plus \(-\Phi\) isolates the part responsible for uniform contraction, but in infinite dimensions the statement “divergence = constant” is only meaningful **after** you specify (or evolve) a reference measure.*  Choose a Gaussian (or another well‑behaved) measure, compute the full \(\nu\)-divergence with formula (2), and then all probabilistic conclusions follow rigorously from the infinite‑dimensional continuity equation.

The divergence of \( U \) is zero under this measure if \( U \) is divergence-free in the flat sense, and if \( U \) is orthogonal to the gradient of the Gaussian weight. To clarify, I’ll show the formula for divergence as \( \text{div}_\nu U = \text{div}_{\text{flat}} U - \int \beta U \), explaining the dynamics with the Gaussian covariance.

parts:
### 1 What it means to “let the Gaussian evolve with the flow”

Write your evolution equation as  

\[
\dot\Phi(t)=V[\Phi(t)] \;=\;U[\Phi(t)]-\Phi(t),
\tag{1}
\]

with \( \operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}U=0\).  
The linear term \(-\Phi\) simply contracts every configuration by the factor \(e^{-t}\):

\[
\Phi_{\text{lin}}(t)=e^{-t}\,\Phi_0 .
\]

So the **push‑forward** of the *standard* centred Gaussian\(\;\gamma_0\sim N(0,I)\) under that linear map is another centred Gaussian with covariance  

\[
\mathrm{Cov}[\gamma_t]=e^{-2t}\,I .
\qquad(\text{equivalently } 
\gamma_t = (e^{-t}\,\mathrm{id})_\#\gamma_0).
\]

We call  

\[
\nu_t:=\gamma_t
\tag{2}
\]

the **co‑moving Gaussian measure**.  
Intuitively “the background volume contracts with the same rate as the \(-\Phi\) part of the flow.”

---

### 2 Divergence formula relative to a measure

For any reference measure \( \nu \) the divergence of a vector field \(B\) is  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}B
=\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}B
-\!\!\int \beta_\nu(x,\Phi)\,B(x)\,dx},
\qquad
\beta_\nu=\frac{\delta}{\delta\Phi}\log\rho_\nu .
\tag{3}
\]

For the Gaussian family (2)  

\[
\rho_{\nu_t}(\Phi)
=\exp\!\Bigl[-\tfrac12 e^{2t}\!\int\!|\Phi(x)|^{2}dx\Bigr],\qquad
\beta_{\nu_t}(x,\Phi)=e^{2t}\,\Phi(x).
\tag{4}
\]

---

### 3 Divergence of each part of \(V\)

* **Linear part \(-\Phi\).**

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}(-\Phi)
  \;=\;-\bigl[\underbrace{\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}(\Phi)}_{=\;\dim\to\infty}\bigr]
      -\!\int e^{2t}\Phi(x)\!\bigl(-\Phi(x)\bigr)\,dx
  = -\infty + e^{2t}\!\!\int\!|\Phi|^{2}.
  \]

  Using the usual finite‑mode approximation one sees that the two infinite terms **cancel exactly**; in fact the map \(\Phi\mapsto e^{-t}\Phi\) is *volume‑preserving* in the Gaussian sense.  Concretely one checks

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}(-\Phi)=0.
  \tag{5}
  \]

* **Incompressible part \(U\).**  
  By assumption \( \operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}U=0\).  Therefore

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}U
  = -\!\int e^{2t}\,\Phi(x)\,U[\Phi](x)\,dx .
  \tag{6}
  \]

  The extra term vanishes **iff**

  \[
  \int \Phi(x)\,U[\Phi](x)\,dx =0
  \quad\text{for every configuration }\Phi .
  \tag{7}
  \]

  This is exactly what happens when \(U\) is of **convolution type with an antisymmetric kernel**:

  \[
  U[\Phi](x)=\int K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy,
  \qquad K(z)=-K(-z),\;K(0)=0 .
  \tag{8}
  \]

  Plug (8) into (7):

  \[
  \int\!\Phi(x)\!\Bigl[\int K(x-y)\Phi(y)\,dy\Bigr]dx
  =\tfrac12\iint\!K(x-y)\bigl[\Phi(x)\Phi(y)-\Phi(y)\Phi(x)\bigr]dxdy=0 .
  \]

  Hence  

  \[
    \boxed{\;\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}U=0\;}
    \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
    \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}V
    =\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}\bigl(U-\Phi\bigr)=0 .
  \tag{9}
  \]

---

### 4 Interpretation

* With the **co‑moving Gaussian background** \( \nu_t \) the full drift \(V\) is **divergence‑free**.  
  The infinite‑dimensional Liouville / continuity equation  

  \[
  \partial_t\rho_t + \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}(\rho_t\,V)=0
  \]

  therefore reduces to \( \partial_t\rho_t=0\).  
  In other words **phase‑space probability density stays constant** relative to the shrinking Gaussian volume.  
* In physical language: the linear contraction \(-\Phi\) squeezes all directions uniformly, while the incompressible convolution \(U\) merely “stirs” the configuration without further compression.  If you **measure volume in the very metric that already shrinks with \(-\Phi\)**, the net flow looks volume‑preserving.

---

### 5 When would you see compression?

* If the kernel \(K\) were *not* antisymmetric, or if you used a **fixed** Gaussian (covariance independent of \(t\)), then the last term in (6) would survive and you would obtain a **strictly negative divergence**, quantifying uniform probability contraction.
* The moral: **divergence is always relative to a chosen measure**.  By letting the measure “ride along” with the deterministic squeezing, you isolate the genuine incompressible part and make the Liouville picture exact.

---

### 6 Take‑away checklist for your system

1. **Define** the time‑dependent Gaussian \( \nu_t = N\!\bigl(0,e^{-2t}I\bigr) \).  
2. **Verify** antisymmetry (8) of your kernel \(K\); this guarantees (7).  
3. **Quote** (9): \( \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}V=0\).  
4. **Conclude** that the probability density of states, when expressed relative to \( \nu_t \), is conserved along the flow; any apparent “uniform shrinking” is already encoded in the evolving background volume.

That is the precise, measure‑theoretic formulation of “\(V\) has constant negative flat divergence but no extra compression beyond the linear \(-\Phi\) piece.”

parts:
Below is the quick arithmetic that tells you exactly what changes when the
kernel **is symmetric** ( \(K(z)=K(-z)\) ) rather than antisymmetric.

---

## 1 Set‑up  

\[
V[\Phi](x)=U[\Phi](x)-\Phi(x),
\qquad
U[\Phi](x)=\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}\!K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy ,
\]

with  

* **symmetric kernel:** \(K(z)=K(-z)\);  
* **zero at the origin:** \(K(0)=0\)  
  ⇒ \(\displaystyle\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}U=\int\frac{\delta U}{\delta\Phi(x)}\,dx
     =\int K(0)\,dx=0\).

As before we put the deterministic squeezing \(-\Phi\) into the **co‑moving
Gaussian**  

\[
\nu_t = \mathcal N\!\bigl(0,e^{-2t}I\bigr),
\qquad
\beta_t(x,\Phi)=e^{2t}\,\Phi(x).
\tag{A}
\]

---

## 2 Divergence relative to \(\nu_t\)

Recall the general identity  

\[
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}B
=\operatorname{div}_{\text{flat}}B
-\!\!\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}\beta_t(x,\Phi)\,B(x)\,dx .
\tag{B}
\]

* **Linear part \(-\Phi.**  
  Exactly as in the antisymmetric case, the two “infinite” terms cancel and  

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}(-\Phi)=0 .
  \tag{C}
  \]

* **Averaging part \(U\).**  
  The flat divergence vanishes ( \(K(0)=0\) ), so  

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}U
  = -\!\!\int e^{2t}\,\Phi(x)\,U[\Phi](x)\,dx .
  \tag{D}
  \]

Put (C) + (D) together:

\[
\boxed{\;
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}V
=
 -\,e^{2t}\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}\Phi(x)\,
      \Bigl[\int K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy\Bigr]dx .
\;}
\tag{E}
\]

---

## 3 Why it is *not* identically zero  

Because \(K\) is **symmetric**, the integrand in (E) is
\[
\iint K(x-y)\,\Phi(x)\Phi(y)\,dx\,dy,
\]
which is **strictly positive** for most (non‑zero) configurations \(\Phi\)
(the kernel integrates to 1, averages are positive).  
Hence \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}V(\Phi)\) fluctuates with \(\Phi\); it is *not* a
constant and certainly not always zero.

*If you compute expectations under \(\nu_t\)* you do get  
\(\mathbb E_{\nu_t}\,[\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}V]=0\) (because
\(\mathbb E_{\nu_t}[\Phi(x)\Phi(y)]=e^{-2t}\delta(x-y)\) and \(K(0)=0\)),
but point‑wise in phase space the flow is **compressible** or **expansive**
depending on the instantaneous field.

---

## 4 Does the measure still matter? Yes

If you had kept the **fixed** standard Gaussian
(\( \beta(\Phi)=\Phi\)) the
prefactor \(e^{2t}\) would disappear,
so the divergence would be
\(-\!\int\!\Phi U\) rather than (E).  A different covariance (say a coloured
noise \(C^{-1}\Phi\) in place of \(\Phi\)) would give
\(-\!\int C^{-1}\Phi\,U\).
Thus both the *magnitude* and even the *sign* of the compressibility term
depend on the reference measure you declare.

There is **no choice of time‑independent Gaussian** that makes (D) vanish
for every configuration unless the kernel is antisymmetric.
(The reason: one can always find a \(\Phi\) having the same symmetry as \(K\),
so the integral is non‑zero whatever covariance you pick.)

---

## 5 What you can safely state

* **Flat‑trace zero** → the only source of compression is the interaction
  with the background measure.
* With the **co‑moving Gaussian** \( \nu_t\) the Liouville equation reads

  \[
  \partial_t\rho_t +U\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t
  = \bigl[e^{2t}\!\iint\!K(x-y)\,\Phi(x)\Phi(y)\,dxdy\bigr]\rho_t .
  \]

  The right‑hand side is *configuration‑dependent*; probability density
  grows along trajectories that happen to align with the kernel, and shrinks
  along others.
* In expectation (averaging over \(\nu_t\)) this source term is zero, so the
  Gaussian ensemble is *mean‑preserving* but **not** incompressible
  point‑wise.

---

### Summary
Because your kernel is **symmetric** (not antisymmetric) the coupling
\(\int\Phi\,U\) does **not** cancel, so the divergence of \(U\) is *zero only in
the flat sense*.  Once a bona‑fide measure is chosen (and one must be chosen in
infinite dimensions) an additional
\(-\int\beta\,U\) term appears, making the full drift \(V\) compressible.
Picking the “shrinking” Gaussian \(\nu_t\) minimises but does not eliminate
that term; no static Gaussian removes it altogether.
Could you find a measure that makes it disappear?

parts:
### Short answer  
For a **symmetric** kernel \(K(z)=K(-z)\) with \(\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}K(z)\,dz=1\) and \(K(0)=0\),

*there is no bona‑fide probability measure on the infinite‑dimensional field space for which the divergence term \(\displaystyle\int\beta\,U\) vanishes for **all** configurations* \(\Phi\).  
The only “measure” that would make it disappear is the unattainable flat (translation‑invariant) Lebesgue measure.

---

## 1 Why the cancellation condition is impossible

Recall

\[
U[\Phi](x)=\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy ,
\qquad
\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}U
= -\!\int \beta(x,\Phi)\,U[\Phi](x)\,dx .
\tag{1}
\]

To make \(\operatorname{div}_{\!\nu}U\) identically **zero** you need

\[
\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}\!\beta(x,\Phi)
      \bigl[K\!*\,\Phi\bigr](x)\,dx=0
\quad\text{for every field }\Phi .
\tag{2}
\]

### 1.1  Linear (Gaussian) candidates  
For a centred **Gaussian** reference measure with covariance operator \(C\),

\[
\beta(x,\Phi)=(C^{-1}\Phi)(x).
\tag{3}
\]

Insert (3) in (2), exchange integrals, and use symmetry of \(K\):

\[
\iint_{\mathbb R^{2}}\!\Phi(y)\,\Phi(z)\,
       \bigl[C^{-1}\!*\,K\bigr](y-z)\,dy\,dz
           =0\quad\forall\;\Phi .
\tag{4}
\]

Because the double integral is a symmetric quadratic form in \(\Phi\),
it can vanish for all \(\Phi\) **only if the kernel**
\(\bigl[C^{-1}\!*\,K\bigr](w)\equiv 0\).
But \(K\) is non‑negative and integrates to 1; \(C^{-1}\) is positive and non‑degenerate; their convolution cannot be identically zero.  
Hence **no non‑degenerate Gaussian** eliminates the divergence.

### 1.2  Non‑Gaussian possibilities  
If you allow a nonlinear \(\beta\), condition (2) requires the functional
\(\beta\) to live in the orthogonal complement of the range of the convolution
operator \(K*\cdot\).  
For a symmetric, integrable kernel with unit mass that range is dense in
\(L^{2}\); the only element orthogonal to it is the zero functional
\(\beta\equiv0\).  
But \(\beta\equiv0\) would mean \(\rho_\nu\) is constant—exactly the forbidden
translation‑invariant “flat” measure.

---

## 2 What you *can* say (and do)

* **Co‑moving Gaussian.**  
  With \(\nu_t=\mathcal N\bigl(0,e^{-2t}I\bigr)\) the mean divergence is zero
  (expectation under \(\nu_t\) cancels), even though pointwise compressibility
  remains:

  \[
  \operatorname{div}_{\!\nu_t}U(\Phi)
  =-e^{2t}\!\!\iint\!K(x-y)\,\Phi(x)\Phi(y)\,dxdy
  \neq 0.
  \]

  The Liouville equation therefore reads
  \(\partial_t\rho_t = [e^{2t}Q(\Phi)]\,\rho_t\)
  with \(Q(\Phi)\) the quadratic form above.

* **Finite‑mode truncations.**  
  For every Galerkin cut‑off to the first \(N\) Fourier modes you do have
  a genuine Lebesgue volume; its divergence is the constant \(-N\).  Taking
  \(N\to\infty\) you recover the intuitive “uniform shrinkage”, but only as a
  formal limit.

* **Entropy balance instead of strict Liouville cancellation.**  
  Even though the divergence cannot be killed, you can compute how the
  density scales:

  \[
  \rho_t(\Phi)=\rho_0(\Phi)
  \exp\!\Bigl\{\!
       \int_0^t\!\!e^{2s}Q\bigl(\Phi_s\bigr)\,ds\Bigr\},
  \]

  where \(Q(\Phi)\) is the quadratic form involving \(K\).
  This gives you the exact probabilistic “shrink/expand” rate.

---

### Final line  
Because \(K\) is **symmetric** and normalised, the contraction it produces
along with a Gaussian background can never be fully offset by any bona‑fide
probability measure.  The best you can do is work with
the time‑scaled Gaussian—which equalises the *mean* divergence—or stay in
finite‑dimensional projections where the flat Lebesgue measure exists.

Ah well mean divergence is likely enough for me. Is it possible to prove that the mean divergence of V is always -1? If possible, what can we say about attractors, taking care to handle the nuances between the finite and infinite dimensional case

Below is a practical way to pin down “uniform contraction” for your flow

\[
\dot\Phi = V[\Phi]=U[\Phi]-\Phi ,
\qquad 
U[\Phi](x)=\int_{\mathbb R^{2}}K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy ,
\tag{1}
\]

when the kernel \(K\) is **symmetric**, \(K(0)=0\) and \(\displaystyle\iint K=1\).

---

## 1 Put everything on a finite torus and truncate

1.  Work on the square torus \(\mathbb T^{2}=[0,2\pi]^{2}\) (so volumes are finite).  
2.  Expand in Fourier modes and keep the first \(N\) wave–vectors  
   \(\{k\in\mathbb Z^{2}:|k|\le N\}\).  
   Denote the Galerkin projector \(P_{N}\Phi\).

   *Dimension*: \(d_{N}=2(2N+1)^{2}\)  (real and imaginary parts for each mode).

The **projected dynamics**

\[
\dot\Phi_{N}=P_{N}U[\Phi_{N}] - P_{N}\Phi_{N}
\tag{2}
\]

lives in \(\mathbb R^{d_{N}}\) where the ordinary Lebesgue measure exists.

---

## 2 Exact phase–volume contraction in finite dimension  

* In coordinates the linear part is \(-\Phi_{N}\); its Jacobian matrix is \(-I_{d_{N}}\).  
  Hence

  \[
  \nabla\!\cdot\!(-\Phi_{N})=-d_{N}.
  \]

* The \(U\)-part has Jacobian with **trace 0** because \(K(0)=0\).

Therefore the *finite‑N divergence is constant*:

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla\!\cdot\!V_{N}=-\,d_{N}} .
\tag{3}
\]

Consequences:

* **Volume element** evolves as  
  \(\displaystyle
    d\mathrm{Vol}_{N}(t)=e^{-d_{N}t}\,d\mathrm{Vol}_{N}(0)\).
* **Mean divergence per degree of freedom**  
  \(d_{N}^{-1}\,\nabla\!\cdot\!V_{N}=-1\).  This ratio is independent of \(N\).

---

## 3 Passage to the infinite‑dimensional limit  

While the total divergence \(-d_{N}\!\to\!-\infty\), the *density*
\[
\frac1{d_{N}}\nabla\!\cdot\!V_{N}\longrightarrow-1
\qquad(N\to\infty)
\]
remains well‑defined.  This is the precise sense in which the flow exhibits a
“uniform contraction rate \(-1\) per mode” in the full phase space.

---

## 4 Mean divergence with a co‑moving Gaussian  

Take the time‑dependent Gaussian on each truncated space

\[
\nu_{N,t}= \mathcal N\!\bigl(0, e^{-2t}I_{d_{N}}\bigr).
\tag{4}
\]

* The linear part \(-\Phi_{N}\) is *volume preserving* in the metric of
  \(\nu_{N,t}\); its divergence relative to \(\nu_{N,t}\) is \(0\).
* For the symmetric kernel the expectation of the nonlinear divergence
  vanishes:

  \[
  \mathbb E_{\nu_{N,t}}
  [\,\nabla_{\!\nu_{N,t}}\!\cdot\,U_{N}]
  \;=\;0
  \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
  \boxed{\;
   \mathbb E_{\nu_{N,t}}
  [\,\nabla_{\!\nu_{N,t}}\!\cdot V_{N}]=-\,d_{N}} .
  \tag{5}
  \]

Dividing by \(d_{N}\) and taking \(N\to\infty\) again gives the **mean
compression rate \(-1\) per degree of freedom**.

---

## 5 Implications for attractors  

### Finite dimension  
Equation (3) implies the **phase volume shrinks exponentially**.  
A standard argument (e.g. Eden–Foias) shows every trajectory enters a
compact absorbing ball of radius \(O(e^{-t})\) and is eventually attracted to a
compact set (global attractor) whose Hausdorff dimension is bounded by the
number of positive Lyapunov exponents, itself controlled by the
volume‑contraction rate.

### Infinite dimension  
*The total volume is zero from the outset,* so classical Liouville
arguments do not give an attractor directly.  
Nevertheless the **per‑mode contraction rate \(-1\)** tells you two things:

1.  **Exponential decay of high Fourier modes.**  
    From (2) one proves  
    \(\|P_{>N}\Phi(t)\|_{L^{2}}\le e^{-t}\|P_{>N}\Phi(0)\|\);  
    hence only finitely many modes stay active for large times.

2.  **Existence of a finite‑dimensional global attractor.**  
    Compactness of the Galerkin limit and uniform mode‑decay imply that the
    full semiflow possesses a global attractor \( \mathcal A \subset L^{2} \) that
    is *finite‑dimensional* in the sense of fractal/Hausdorff dimension  
    (standard theorem of infinite‑dimensional dissipative systems).  
    The bound on \(\dim_{H}\mathcal A\) can be expressed in terms of the
    per‑mode contraction (here essentially “one real degree of freedom lost per
    unit time”) and the size of the nonlinear forcing \(U\).

---

## 6 Take‑away  

* **Yes – you can prove the *mean* divergence of \(V\) is \(-1\) per degree of
  freedom.**  Work in any finite Fourier truncation, compute the constant
  divergence (3), then normalise by dimension and let
  \(N\!\to\!\infty\).
* This uniform contraction yields a **finite‑dimensional global attractor** for
  the infinite‑dimensional flow, even though no bona‑fide volume form exists
  in the full space.  Probabilistically, densities relative to the shrinking
  Gaussian collapse onto that attractor while preserving total probability.

thoughts.content: The user claims their system shows two attractors: a dynamic one and a zero attractor, which seems contradictory to previous reasoning predicting just one. It’s possible the system can exhibit multiple attractors, depending on the initial conditions. For small norms, the zero attractor might dominate, but larger norms could lead to another limit cycle or invariant set. Nonlinear coupling could create nontrivial invariant manifolds, allowing higher-dimensional dynamics even with monotone contraction in each mode. This suggests that multiple attractors may exist under specific conditions.

parts:
### Why “uniform contraction on average” does **not** force a single attractor  

The calculation we did last time shows that every **finite Galerkin truncation**

\[
\dot\Phi_N \;=\; P_NU[\Phi_N]\;-\;\Phi_N
\]

has a constant **negative** divergence  
\(\nabla\!\cdot V_N=-d_N\).  
That implies

* **volumes shrink exponentially**;
* trajectories are ultimately confined to a compact set of finite dimension.

What it **doesn’t** say is that *all trajectories have to collapse onto the **same** invariant set*.  
A contracting flow can still possess several disjoint, compact, invariant sets, each with its own basin of attraction.  
(Think of the 1‑D ODE \( \dot x = -x + \tanh x\): divergence = \(-1\) everywhere, yet there are two stable fixed points.)

---

## 1 Your two attractors fit this picture

| attractor | what it is | possible basin |
|-----------|------------|----------------|
| **zero attractor** | the trivial equilibrium \(\Phi\equiv 0\) | initial fields with sufficiently small norm (damping wins) |
| **“dynamic” attractor** | a non‑trivial invariant set (limit cycle, rotating wave, or steady pattern) solving \( U[\Phi]=\Phi \) | initial data whose average energy is above a threshold |

### Why the convolution can support a non‑zero equilibrium  
Because the kernel is **symmetric**, integrates to **1**, and satisfies \(K(0)=0\),  
the fixed‑point equation

\[
U[\Phi](x)=\int K(x-y)\,\Phi(y)\,dy=\Phi(x)
\]

admits non‑zero solutions whenever the convolution operator has eigenvalue 1.  
Typical scenario on the torus:

* eigenfunctions are Fourier modes;
* the eigenvalue in mode \(k\) is \(\widehat K(k)\);
* if \(\widehat K(k_*)=1\) for some \(k_*\neq 0\) you get a continuous family \( \Phi(x)=A\cos(k_*\!\cdot x)+B\sin(k_*\!\cdot x)\).  
Damping \(-\Phi\) pushes the amplitude toward an \(O(1)\) value, so
the orbit settles on a finite‑dimensional torus (“dynamic attractor”).

---

## 2 How contraction and multiple attractors coexist

1. **Phase volume shrinks** inside *each* basin, but the basins themselves are separated by **stable manifolds** (zero‑measure “walls”).  
   Volume cannot cross those walls, so nothing forces the two basins to merge.

2. The **global attractor** (in the formal Foias sense) is the *union* of all bounded invariant sets.  
   In your case it is the disjoint union  
   \( \mathcal A = \{0\}\;\cup\;\mathcal A_{\text{dyn}}\).  
   The dimension estimate we derived applies to each component individually and to their union.

---

## 3 What you can prove rigorously

* **Existence of both invariant sets.**  
  *Zero* is obvious.  
  A fixed‑point/degree argument on the projected equation (or a bifurcation calculation if \(\widehat K(k)\) crosses 1) gives \(\mathcal A_{\text{dyn}}\).

* **Basins of attraction.**  
  Energy‑like Lyapunov functional  
  \(E(\Phi)=\tfrac12\|\Phi\|_{L^2}^{2}\) satisfies  

  \[
  \dot E = -\|\Phi\|_{L^{2}}^{2} + \langle \Phi, U[\Phi]\rangle .
  \]

  Because \(K\) is positive, the second term grows like \(E\) for large amplitudes but is \(o(E)\) near zero.  
  Result:  
  – if \(E(0)<E_c\)  ⇒ \(\dot E<0\) ⇒ attraction to \(0\);  
  – if \(E(0)>E_c\)  ⇒ solution crosses to the basin of \(\mathcal A_{\text{dyn}}\).

* **Finite‑dimensionality** of \(\mathcal A\).  
  Our uniform per‑mode contraction rate \(-1\) yields a bound on the number of active Fourier modes after transients (Lieb‑Thirring type argument).  Both attractors live in the span of those modes.

---

## 4 Infinite vs. finite dimension—subtleties handled

| issue | finite‑N truncation | limit \(N\to\infty\) |
|-------|--------------------|----------------------|
| phase volume | ordinary Lebesgue, shrinks \(e^{-d_Nt}\) | no global volume; contraction interpreted per‑mode |
| attractor | compact subset of \(\mathbb R^{d_N}\) | projective limit of those sets ⇒ global attractor in \(L^{2}\) |
| uniqueness | may have several components | same components persist; global attractor is their union |
| dimension bound | \(\dim_H\mathcal A_N\lesssim C\) (independent of \(N\)) | passes to limit; \(\dim_H\mathcal A<\infty\) |

---

### Bottom line

*Mean divergence \(-1\) per mode guarantees overall **dissipation and finite‑dimensional long‑time behaviour**, but it does **not** force uniqueness of the attracting set.*  
With your symmetric kernel the dynamics supports at least two invariant sets—a trivial fixed point and a non‑trivial “dynamic” set—and the phase space splits into corresponding basins.  
All conclusions about contraction, probability transport, and dimension remain valid **within each basin**.
